awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Discrete Choice Estimation with Partially Observable States and Hidden Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will investigate rigorous methods for data-driven model identification and estimation for stochastic dynamic decision processes.  Many dynamical systems are modeled via discrete states that evolve via stochastic transitions and control inputs. Rather than assume a model structure in advance, this project develops methods to "learn" the model structure, including preferences of the controller and model states, from available data.  The project will develop these new methods in the context of technology-assisted human performance in vehicle operations.  Humans drivers operating vehicles on a busy highway often engage in secondary tasks that demand cognitive effort (e.g. attending to a business-related phone call, listening to a podcast). The driver is aware of their engagement in the secondary task but may be only imperfectly aware of its effect on their own ability to drive safely. On-board autonomous technology with the ability to accurately estimate the driver’s safety level may improve performance through auditory warnings or partial automation (e.g., adaptive cruise control). However, existing estimation methodologies are built on the assumption that the driver has perfect state observability, whereas the driving task’s overall level of safety is only imperfectly observed. This project provides a novel estimation method to build a predictive model of the agent’s driving behavior by considering imperfectly observed driving states (e.g. safe and unsafe driving). The research benefits the society by enabling on-board automation system to monitor the driver's activities and potentially intervene to improve driving performance and safety.

This award will develop new methodologies and algorithms for learning a model of dynamic decisions with hidden states. The research draws on and generalizes dynamic discrete choice models to consider memoryless partially observable states. This project will also examine estimation of (non-exponential) semi-Markov hidden models with state-dependent sojourn time distributions.  This research will rigorously examine whether and/or under what conditions the models are identifiable and ascertain the implications for robustness of estimation results. The new methods will leverage experimental collection of observable data known to correlate with distraction (e.g., breathing rate, heart rate variability, eye-tracking) together with observed actions (e.g., maneuvers) to estimate a compact model of the agent's control policies and the dynamics of partially observable states (safe and unsafe driving). The model and estimation approach will be validated through a high-fidelity driving simulation study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Award Title: Dynamic Discrete Choice Estimation with Partially Observable States and Hidden Dynamics: Application to Human-Autonomy Interaction
Award Number: 2048395
Principal Investigator: Dr. Yanling Chang
Co-Principal Investigators: Dr. Alfredo Garcia, Dr. Maryam Zahabi
Institution: Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station

Overview:

This project developed novel estimation methods and intervention strategies aimed at improving human-autonomy interaction in driving scenarios. The research addressed the challenges posed by imperfect self-awareness of drivers regarding the impact of secondary tasks (e.g., phone calls, reading Google Maps) on their driving safety. By leveraging partially observable driving states (e.g., safe and unsafe driving), the project aimed to enable on-board automation systems to estimate driver safety levels accurately and implement strategies, such as auditory warnings, to help drivers mitigate risks and enhance driving performance.

Key Results:

  • Intellectual Merit:
    The project successfully advanced structural estimation methodologies for hidden semi-Markov decision-making processes, allowing for general sojourn time distributions that account for more realistic state transitions between safe and unsafe driving conditions. This represents a significant extension of classical Markov models, addressing dynamic, partially observable environments.

    • A rigorous identifiability analysis was performed to confirm that the parameters of the semi-Markov models are uniquely estimable, enhancing confidence in the model's predictive accuracy.

    • The methods were validated through a high-fidelity driving simulation study using physiological data (e.g., eye-tracking) alongside driver actions (e.g., vehicle maneuvers). This work demonstrated that human decision-making under partial observability can be effectively modeled and predicted.

  • Broader Impacts:
    The project contributed significantly to highway safety research by creating models that allow smarter on-board automation systems to monitor and predict unsafe driver states. This work has immediate implications for reducing traffic accidents caused by cognitive distractions.

    • A pilot study demonstrated the interaction between cognitive task difficulty and driving safety under secondary task engagement. Participants exhibited increased reaction times and a higher frequency of unsafe driving behaviors, such as late braking, as cognitive task complexity increased. These findings highlight the measurable impact of cognitive load on driving performance. These results validate the proposed interventions for adaptive and personalized on-board warnings.

    • The project supported workforce development by training three graduate students and ten undergraduate students, who contributed directly to publications, data collection, and experimental research in modeling, simulation, and data analytics. Research outcomes were disseminated through five peer-reviewed journal articles, with an additional manuscript pending submission.

Broader Societal Implications:

The outcomes of this research are expected to significantly enhance highway safety by reducing accidents caused by driver distraction and delayed reactions. By enabling on-board systems to assist drivers more effectively, this project contributes to progress in reducing highway fatalities and promotes safer roadways. Additionally, the methodologies developed have broader applications in other domains requiring dynamic decision-making under uncertainty, such as mental fatigue and healthcare.

Public Accessibility:

The results of this project were shared through standard academic dissemination methods, including conferences and peer-reviewed journals.

Future Directions:

Building on this foundation, future research will explore real-world implementation of the validated models. Key directions include collaboration with automotive industry partners to integrate real-time data from connected vehicles, allowing on-board systems to dynamically adapt to changing driver states and road conditions. The team will also investigate the scalability of these methods in diverse driving environments and other human-autonomy interaction scenarios.
